38792645.review:
TL;DR: An impressive experience and lots of fun.

Long-ish version: H3VR was a surprise. I didn't expect much from it, really. Just some sort of a fun-ish shooting gallery, I was ok with that since I was mostly looking for that and I like shooting guns. For someone, like me, who's from a country where it's a bit more complicated to do that, it was a cool idea.

But shit, was I in for quite a ride! Sure, there's your basic shooting gallery mode, and it's done well... But SO MANY GUNS! And they're all insanely well-made, all animated almost perfectly, as you'd expect an RL gun to actually move and work. The sounds are really great, each gun has its own moving parts, and has its own feeling. And there's so many of them! Even old weird stuff, like that old breech-loading pistol. It wasn't really necessary for the devs to add that, but it's still there! 

And of course, there are all the experimental modes, like the zombie mode or the survival horror one, the take & hold, ... none of those modes are as studied as they could, but they're more than enough fun to keep you busy for a while. Unlike most VR games I tried so far, I'm actually looking forward to my next play session.

Finally, the devs themselves. Anton keeps updating the game with love, and he keeps close to his community, with a lot of meaningful interaction on the subreddit, as well as the more than welcome (and well-made) weekly videos and devlogs. 

In a word: wonderful!

38645351.review: This is hands down my favorite VR game.  The developer, Anton Hand, is a huge part in that.  This is his labor of love, and he faithfully updates the game - making it leaps and bounds better every few months.  The gestures for controlling the firearms is amazing.  Shooting at the range is more satisfying than many other VR shooters.  On top of that, Anton added various AI bots to fight in different arenas.  The game has limitless potential in the VR venue.  The quality of gameplay is nicely complemented by Anton's sense of humor.  There is a thin strand of plot in Wurstworld, one of the main attractions in the game, but boy let me tell you - the unraveling mystery had my riveted.  Half-Life 3 should be VR, and it should be developed by Anton Hand.

38603614.review:
This is how you do early access games. 

The dev(s) is/are great and constantly interact with the community via Reddit & Youtube. Features and content are regularly added, the core mechanics are well-thought-out and implemented well, you could even call it polished.

I've only played with Vive but I hear the Rift works well too. There are multiple locomotion mechanics (teleport/dash/smooth locomotion and more) which I've had no trouble with.

All of the weapons in the game are beautifully modelled and all the mechanics of all the guns are true to life and work well. The sound design is good and the sounds used are good quality.

The game features multiple (and customisable) play modes: target ranges, arena fights, simulated room-breaching, horror-esque survival modes, a wild-west themed progressive, uh, theme park thing with guns, seasonal festive modes, and even an EA Games "Sense of pride and accomplishment" simulator mode.

Also, everything is meat themed. Which is nice.

Buy it, you won't be disappointed.

38342274.review:
Freaking awesome! A very realistic firearm simulator. Being a firearm owner myself the realism I must say is almost perfect. There are a few minor things here and there, like the selector for full auto on the AK being in the wrong position, but dang this game is so awesome it makes up for that. It is so realistic you can take magazines spawned with a specific gun and use it in another gun of a different type if it accepts that mag in real life. You can even load individual cartridges into mags, so for example if you accidently eject a live cartridge you can pick it up and put it back in the mag. It's crazy detailed like that.

The game part, although small is kind of fun. This is really more for just messing around than actually playing a "game", but it is still fun. I found some of the instructions and such difficult to follow, but once you figure it out you can have some entertainment. 

Honestly though if you just like going to the shooting range, or have always wanted to play with firearms then this is a must have. It pretty much is like a range day, but you can spawn any weapon in the game you want. Different accessories like silencers, sights and scopes, lasers and flashlights. Ammunition of multiple types, even of the same round, such as tracer, AP, HP, FMJ, etc). And some other fun tools which also make good weapons (hammer, crow bar, and more).

A few things I hope to see in the future (in case the devs read these reviews):
- ability to spawn explosives using the ammo spawner, like 40 mm grenades, RPG's, etc.
- ability to manipulate fire selector on all guns using non-dominant hand grip (AK selector for example, like you can on the L85A2)
- improve visibility of the red dot sights (they are way too dim, even for daylight)
- MORE super realistic guns! Some belt fed machineguns and grenade and rocket launchers, etc. But all I can say is keep the quality going, so if that means it is a slow process that is fine with me. This should be the ultimate firearms simulator, and it's got a hell of a solid start.
- More detailed realism on some things that are lacking, like having to line up the primer on RPG's when inserted into the RPG-7. Grenades not arming until X amount of meters after launch. 
- More maps and more targets and fun things to shoot at... like challenging targets 
- Keep up the great work!

38229978.review:
The definitive implementation of guns in VR. Every other VR shooter dev should be buying this game and taking notes. Anton has been cracking the problems of guns in VR wide open for years, and he has set a high bar for others to reach.

If you're not into guns very much, good news! H3 isn't about murdering waves of humans! The developer isn't crazy about the violence or 'gun culture.' He seems to be focused on replicating the physical simulation of these machines in a very faithful way.

Totally into guns? Good news! H3 is a wonderland of highly realistic firearms, lovingly simulated for you to customize, learn about and deploy in challenging scenarios! While the targets don't bleed, everything else about the game makes it worth your time. No, you don't get to blast terrorists or zombies, but if you appreciate the art of mastering weapons, some of which you'll never lay your real-steel hands on in your lifetime, you'll get a kick out of this game.

Simply put, its a playground filled with guns that can't hurt you or anyone else. Even if you're currently wearing an NRA hat and strapped with a match grade USP .45 with suppressor, you'll appreciate the joy of messing around with these boom-sticks without fear of pissing off a range officer or DNR do-gooder. Dispense with your political leanings and enjoy!

38229393.review:
Let my start by saying this is my OPINION of the game that should be taken as such.  I have gone into this knowing it is EA and therefore things are being added and changed over time. However, this is my opinion of the game at the time of this review, after over a year in EA development.

     When looking through the top rated games for VR, this is always near the top. When looking at the games currently being played, this is either at the very top or near the top. After playing this myself for 2 hours, I have come to the conclusion...that I have no fucking idea why. 
    
THE PROS
     -This is a 1 man dev team making this. He puts out regular updates via youtube and seems really excited about what he does. He seems to actually listen to his community and makes changes in game based on the requests of this community. I have to give him props for that. This is something I love to see and so the dev gets an A+ just for this,
     -The detail put into the guns is amazing. From meshes to detailed safety switches to bolt action movements are all on point. Even though I have not been close to many real world guns, I believe the ones in this are close to if not exact replicas. The fact that you must go through the motions of putting a magazine into a gun, and then pulling back the slide to ready it is really nice to see. I wish more games would take notes from this and implement it.
     -It feels like a really great simulation. You can go into a shooting range, pick from a WIDE assortment of guns and attachments, and then go nuts on a paper target or other objects.

THE CONS (IMO)
     -The whole concept of the game AI is that you're fighting against....hotdogs, hence the title. I get that. However, after the detail put into the guns, it kinda pulls you out of the immersion only getting to shoot at dissected hotdogs.
     -There's really not much "game" here. It feels as if you're playing a giant tutorial that you never actually pass. There are numerous shooting ranges, ranging in style and utility. Also at the time of playing, there are a few minigames. They range from a B-movie horror scenario where you're trying to find chunks of meat to throw into a grinder in the spawn area while dodging traps and killer robot hotdogs, to a capture-the-point scenario where you take points from AI hotdogs and hold them for a predetermined amount of time. There is even a zombie wave shooter thrown in there. While these game modes were neat at first, I really couldnt justify the price point for the amount of "game" in this. I do acknowlege again, however, that this game is EARLY ACCESS and this could change over time

So in conclusion, if you're a "gun nut" who lives and breathes gunpowder, then by all means this is a must have. If you have a slight interest in guns and just want to relax while putting some virtual bullets down range, then also this should be in your library. However, if you are looking for a game with a good amount of different things to do with the nice gun physics and attention to detail, then you might be disappointed like I was. By all means, this is not a HORRIBLE game. However, I still cannot understand why it is one of the top rated VR games on steam.

38127637.review:
On paper, this game sounds pretty dull; shoot a variety of guns at targets. In reality it is one of the best VR experiences out there, and I think that can largely be attributed to the quality control and attention to detail put into the game by its dev. I don't particularly love guns in real life and I find the idea of owning/shooting gun kind of intimidating, but this has really been enlightening for me as an educational tool. The level of realism for each gun is so high, that after 20ish years of gaming where the majority of games involve guns and shooting of some kind, I was shocked to find that with an M-16 in my hands I had no clue how to actually fire it. All the small things; loading the right clip, flicking the safety, racking the slide, fiddling with the sights and attachments... I absolutely loved it as a learning experience. Plus, the little things, like I didn't know that after loading and racking a pistol, removing the clip still leaves one bullet in the chamber that can be fired. It was therefore surprising to me when I accidentally shot my virtual foot off, thinking the gun was safely unloaded. To me, this is one of those things where even if you are the most liberal, anti-gun person in real life, it's a damn good thing to at least understand how they work from a safety/preparedness point of view!

But it's not all educational and serious; In fact, for a game about realistic, lethal weapons, H3VR does an incredible job at not taking itself too seriously! There's tons of fun to be had with all sorts of varying game modes, from straight up target shooting at a range, to swinging out of the ceiling whilst shooting in a jungle gym type arena, to the terrifyingly intense meat grinder mode. As well as being able to spawn items to mess around with without limitation, there is also the ability to reset the environment back to its clean, original state. The variety of guns is large and fantastic, with a huge amount of quality and care in each one. With one exception, they are all true to their real life counterparts, but that one exception is a fictitious gun, the Cleric's pistol from the film Equilibrium (which was a total dream to get to shoot!). There are also some melee weapons to mess around with, as well as throwables and then some straight up silly items.

Graphically, the game is so well done. The guns and textures look amazing and some of the best I've seen in VR. The audio too is absolutely top marks, with fantastic attention to detail being placed on little things from the crack of the different calibers to the plink of the bullet casings hitting the floor. Gunfire also takes into consideration environmental reverb, so a rifle shot doesn't sound the same in the gunrange as it does outside. All these small things do such a good job at making the experience feel realistic.

The physics are excellent, with the ability to change how physics work from realistic to semi-realistic, or to not at all. I love realistic because I love the "feel" of the guns when you toss them on a table, though tossing grenades with realistic physics is a little tricky! I also absolutely love that the option is given to have no bullet casing cleanup, so you can see all the casings pile up on the floor. Other than that, interacting with guns can at times be a little niggly, especially with the Touch controllers, but I mostly chalk that other up to just the nature of doing anything with the motion controllers, plus a recent update helped tremendously with Touch calibration. 

Because of the mostly standing nature of the game, VR sickness was non-existent for me. You can move around the areas with a teleport, which works perfectly fine. I have no complaints about this game at all, but I do have two disappointments, of which sadly the debates on each have been soundly put to rest! I would have liked to (or the option to) been able to see my hands in game for immersion. However, due to the understandable technical difficulties in this task and potential bugginess it could cause, it isn't going to happen. But even more than that I wish so much that H3VR had a Workshop on Steam where modders could create fictitious guns from sci-fi or movies (like the RoboCop gun, Blade Runner, etc, or maybe even crazy things like a Proton Pack!). However, due to the complexity of adding guns and their physics, the game wouldn't be able to support the architecture for modders, so it is a sound no on that. The absence of these two thing are disappointing in the truest sense of the word, but in no way make the game any less incredible.

Even though its Early Access, the current game is polished like a full release. Updates have been consistent and substantial in content, with the dev being active on the forums and engaging with the community. If you love guns, this is a must play game. If you don't love guns, this is a must play game.

This game is great, especially for someone like me who JUST bought their first VR system. With all of the different game modes, from shooting galleries and tacticool sandboxes to the nail-biting Meat Grinder, alongside tons of different options for figuring out which VR movement and controls suit you best, this game should really be the "Wii Sports" of VR - a quintessential package that every VR gamer should pick up, and fire up whenever friends come over to check out your new rig.

I'm playing this on an Oculus with Touch Controllers and haven't had any issues. Learning all of the different controllers for toggling safeties and dropping mags takes a little while, but once you've got the hang of it, reloading and such during some of the arena/combat modes is a thrill. The fact that you can "holster" weapons is awesome too - it feels awesome to know I've got a handy hatchet on my left hip and a big "eff off" shotgun on my right.

Well worth the money if you've got a VR system! I can't recommend "Arm-Swinger" movement enough - in my opinion its easily the best way to play VR. No teleportation, and none of the motion sickness I get from joystick movement either.

37015942.review:
The short and sweet of it: If you have a Vive or Oculus Rift, you should also get this game.  It's one of the few must-have VR games out there right now.  And while I can't speak to how the game feels with a Vive (maybe someday), it's great on the Rift's Touch controllers.

Personally, I really enjoy the reflex ranges with the pistol courses.  There's a viscreal satisfaction to acing them that's hard to put to words.

The pro's:
+The audio is distinctively satisfying.  Whether it's the thoont of the M79 grenade launcher, or the BRRRRRT of the mini-gun.  Even the noises the various mags make as they slide out of the pistols is a treat.
+The simulation can be incredibly deep if you want it to be.  You can set yourself up as if you've gone out to an actual indoor range with only so many magazines to work with and a simulated box of ammo.  Where every couple of minutes you have to go through the motions of loading up your mags a shell at a time.
+Or you can go at it without a care in the world and blow through thousands of dollars worth of virtual ammunition in minutes using the infinite spawn toggle for your holsters.
+The controls are more often than not really intuitive on the Rift's Touch controllers.
+Steadilly growing at the time of review; new guns and ranges are being added every few months.
+Dual-wield Saiga 12's without destroying your shoulders!
+Yes, there's a mini-gun.

The con's:
-Slow to load.  The game will load up just fine, but then I usually end up standing around the range select room for a few minutes before I can actually select a range to load up.
-Loading mags into the guns can sometimes be a little fiddly with the more realistic loading option.  This is mostly due to a lack of tactile feedback.  But some of it is chalked up to how the magazines orient themselves in conjunction with the controllers in virtual space, and how the controllers end up "interacting" in actual space.
-Sometimes the controls aren't all that intuitive..  But more often than not, there's instuctions on the weapon spawn menu.  Plus, there are some guns that just aren't all that intuitive.
-Lack of tactile forms make shooting the rifles a little less satisfying.

TL;DR: Grenade Skee-Ball.  Need I say more?

36850773.review:
Actuellement une des "experiences"/jeux en VR les plus exaltante.

Certe ce n'est pas ultra scripté, bourré d'action ou gorgé de niveau lineaire, de missions scenarisé. Non c'est une multitude de champ de tire et quelques arenes/niveaux avec des adversaires IA. Il y a meme une grosse map avec pas mal de petite activité secondaire, d'objet a trouver, d'enigme a résoudre, etc... en plus du tir. 

Bref, c'est actuellement un enorme bac a sable proposant des dizaines (voir plus) d'entrainement specifique et contextualisé et d'autre map un peu plus ouverte... Pour profiter d'une collection d'arme et les utiliser en prenant bien soin de respecter la realité et les specificités de chaque equipement.

La moindre cartouche est modélisé et sera utilisable en la glissant dans le fut de l'arme si elle le permet, le moindre chargeur pourra être vidé ou rempli balle par balle, les armes ont des cran de sécurité, des culasse mobile, des trepieds, des selecteur de cadence de tir, des rails pour placer lunette et laser.

Ce jeu est au FPS ce qu'ARMA est a Call of Duty. L'enorme satisfaction qui découle des parties c'est la maitrise du comportement et du fonctionnement, ce n'est pas enchainé des 360 noscope, mais bien de subir un echange de feu contre des "bandits" (a la modelisation certe... hum... mais c'est le delire du jeu aussi qui veut ça), en comptant chaque cartouche, et en se planquant a couvert le temps de remettre des balles dans le barillet, tout en regrettant d'avoir peut être mal choisi vos armes, une avec moins de peps, ou moins joli, mais permettant une recharge rapide plutot que cartouche par cartouche. Et puis finalement a bout portant lacher votre carabine et empoigné un canon scié, inutile a longue distance mais terrible au contact. Ou passer 2h a vous entrainer dans divers tir sur cible "scenarisé"

De plus les developpeurs rajoutent du contenu de maniere extremement reguliere, tous les 3 a 4 semaines on a droit a une mise a jour genereuse (nouvelle arme, nouvelle map, amelioration des effets graphique), c'est un early access extremement serieux et deja tres genereux.

Je le range avec joie au coté d'Arizona Sunshine, UltraWings, Lunar Flight et Vanishing Realms, comme experience/jeu VR de grande qualité (et avec un potentiel parfaitement incroyable si ils continuent a ce rythme)

36630668.review:
I've done my best to try and write this review, but there's simply no way to say how good H3VR is.

 Most VR games at the moment seem to lack content; resembling glorified demos with hefty price tags. H3VR isn't one of these games, instead being one of the best examples of game development on the market. The dev doesn't sit behind their desk and ignore the community, but actively takes part in discussions on the game and it's future. They don't hide the process of creation of the game, providing many videos that detail the development from now to when the game didn't even have a name.

In the past 6 months, the game has had many updates that seek to add variety to the game; transforming it from a simple gun range simulator into something much more. For example, new modes include an updated version of last years Halloween mode Meat Grinder, a more comedic Halloween experience in the form of Rise of The Rotweiners, a new capture point style mode called Take & Hold on the beta branch and a large Western mode complete with activities called WurstWorld.

Many Early Access games fail to properly justify the investment of consumers. H3VR is one of the few games to actually do this properly, providing plenty of past content that reassures future buyers that more content is on the way, instead of a purchase being a leap of faith for the person who takes it. For £15, you're getting a ton of content and the promise of more as time passes.

36467866.review:
I don't know why I keep coming back to H3VR, but it's become my go-to game for blowing off steam in VR. I usually like deep, boring games where you stare at a map moving sliders around, or walk around an island thinking about the meaning of life. But in H3VR, I can grab a Desert Eagle, slide a magazine in, pull back the slide and watch the first bullet enter the chamber, then grab a second gun and blast away. And it's [i]amazing[/i].
There are more and more gun-shootin' games on VR like Pavlov and BAM, but none of them feels quite as right as H3VR - just the satisfying feeling of slamming a magazine into a MP5 and slapping the bolt forward like all the best action heroes is almost worth the money by itself.

And it's funny because the game seems pretty straightforward - it's a sandbox with a collection of weapons ranging from antique pistols to modern tacticool M4s with all the trimmings, a couple of shooting ranges, and some challenges with mobile hot dog opponents or target discs. As a non-American who's only shot a gun once, there's something incredibly relaxing about simple target practice, blasting wooden cutouts with a pump-action shotgun or sniping watermelons with a .50 anti-materiel rifle while lying on the floor of my room. After years of playing FPS games, it's amazing to actually experience a M1 Garand up close, or create my own reflex-sighted-flashlighted-scoped UMP45. Oh, and it has Deckard's pistol from Blade Runner. I mean, isn't that an instant buy in itself?

Nothing else on VR - even non-shooting games - feels quite as [i]right[/i] as H3VR. There's tons of updates (can't wait for the upcoming WW2 one), which brings me back every month as I go through the menus and try out all the unusual new weapons that have been added in. I love the developer's sense of humour, which transforms what could have been a capable but sterile gun simulator into a VR masterpiece.

36462422.review: This VR game is well worth the money.  Hats off to the hard working dev Anton as well.  You ARE AWESOME man!  If you like guns and want a good shooting game that keeps getting better and better get HOT DOGS, HORSESHOES AND HAND GRENADES now!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

36451843.review:
First off I will add to this review as significant content is added. New and interesting game modes are often enough to keep the game fresh during the early access period to such a point that the sheer ammount of game modes will probably be intimidating to new players at release. New guns are being added all the time necessitating players to practice with the different mechanics some guns use in order to do the more demanding game modes. Knowledge of how guns work. is important. Different mechanics for guns include but are not limited to: Breach loading, lever action, closed bolt, open bolt, clip loaded, magazine loaded, dual fire selectors, and magazine catches. The game treats every gun in a unique way and if you don't know how to use the weapon in a fast pased game mode you'll run into trouble. Thankfully the game has a large number of differen shooting ranges that let you learn or simply have a little fun. The number of weapons even at this point is impressive.

The game supports a good number of different movement modes that range from immersive to comfortable. Personally i like the armswinger mode that allows you to run have very fine tune moving at the expense of the ability to reload while running. It's great for immersion. 

The enemies while great targets are uninteresting to look at and are quite dumb in terms of AI. The slicers are very cool and interesting to fight(in melee) but are pretty easy to deal with with guns and cannot path very well. The clunk mk2 is the star of the show in terms of design. Having internal and external parts that can be damaged to disable the tanklike robot in a multitude of ways. The problem is that it is not implemented well yet, has a dumb ai, and has very few offensive  abilities. The problem with implementation is that when you spawn them they just all spawn in one place on the lowest level of the map that you would think would be the most fun to fight them. They never try to take a position that would be beneficial to them and they will often sit and wait for the player in places where the player can shoot at them without reprocussion( they cannot aim high). They only have one weapon that can be easily outmaneuvered since the projectiles are slow. The final and most common enemy is the weinerbot. It has several forms(zombie, bandit, soldier) and can have one of many weapons and armour types. The're ok to shoot at but not really immersive. However their simplicity does allow there to be ALLOT of them spawned at the same time which can be challenging and fun. 

There are a large number of sandbox levels, a few challenge/score levels, and a few objective levels to play in. There are 3 levels that are the most important to talk about. First off is the arena prototype, it's just a large area with lots of catwalks and places to take cover you can turn on auto spawning and just run around shooting to get the hang of your guns or take cover and practice that way. The newest level where you capture and defend strategic points and loot for different guns and atachments. The meat grinder, horror/comedy themed survival mode with puzzles. There are quite a few more but these are where I spen the majority of my time playing. There is the friendly45 range which looks quite similar to the gun range in the youtube channel hickock45 witch is my favorite range to just play around It needs a way to add more targets to the scene permanently and a way to reset the targets without losing the guns you're using though. 

Overally the game is worththe money at it's current point. It has allot more content to offer than other shooter games and has an unnatural level of polish for it's point in development. However it's a game that requires some time to get accustomed to so it doesn't do well as a party game. It is however a good look at the potential that vr has.

36186363.review:
最高の銃器操作シミュレーターである
一般的なVRFPSとは違い、このゲームは銃器を操作、撃つ楽しさを全面的フォーカスしており、
「なんだ、またVRガンシューか」と思ってスルーしようとしたあなた、ちょっと待ってほしい。

このゲームは銃器の操作、細かい可動パーツ（折り畳み式アイアンサイト、ストックなど）
そして照準具のゼロイン、果たして実物で使える一部の小技、テクニック、カスタムまで再現可能。
装備の設置もどの手で使用するのも自由でありサバゲーや射撃競技で馴染みたホルスター設置の高さやスリングなど、
別の人気VRFPSであるOnwardではできなかった、近年のCQB戦で頻繁に行う持ち手を切り替えるテクニックまでできる。
あらゆるオブジェクトも物理エンジンで演算されており、
マガジンをしっかり挿入口に合わせてから挿入ないとリロードすらまともにできない本格仕様です。（設定でオフ可能）

そして実銃通りどの銃でも微妙に持ち角度が違っており、
気に入った銃をしっかり使い慣れればホルスターからの早撃ちもでき、
リロードの正確さも実際スキルアップされるので達成感溢れるロマン仕様です。

最近のアップデートで対NPC戦要素を本格的実装され、
スリル満点な本格的戦闘を体験できるようになった。

サバゲでリロードがほぼ必要ない、エイミングすら弾道だ寄りな電動ガンを使い慣れたサバゲーマー、
一度はこのゲームやってみればチャージングハンドルの操作忘れ、セフティーの外し忘れ癖が目立つのでしょう。
実際何人かのサバゲー好き友人をやらせて大体そこで引っかかっていました。笑

一人の部屋でエアガンを弄ったり遊んだり、操作や眺めるのが好きなのであれば、
間違いなく買いです。たっだ千円で自分専用のシューティングレンジをお手に入れよう。

マルチ対応する待ったなしです！

36152691.review:
Easily my favorite VR game. Every VR game I purchase now must compare somehow to this; It must run as well as this does, (exceptionally well, though there is the occasional, though acceptable, stutter), it must control as well as this does, (once again, exceptionally well), and it must be as fun or more fun as this is. (exceptionally so.)

I've found a game or two that have met the first two requirements...
But none have yet to reach the third.

Anyway, it's basically a realistic gun/shooting simulator, with a lot of other stuff as well, (i.e. medieval swords, grenade skeeball, etc.) There are several game modes, such as Meatgrinder or the newly added Rotweiners, in which you fight sausage-themed enemies in different environments with the expertly programmed weapons and items. The game is truly exceptional, and easily has the most dedicated and honest dev I have ever seen.
ALL PRAISE LORD ANTON!

36135236.review:
Ive been doing sport and competative shooting since I was a teenager. This game hits it all on the head. Apart from from a few issues within the game's engine, its utterly brilliant.

The selection of weaponry ranges from the common to the delightfully obscure. All fully articulate and modeled to perfection.

Game modes include combat simulations, arcade target shooting and sandbox ranges to play with to your hearts content.

Yes, there are some issues. VR still being in its infancy restricts potential greatly. Long range rifles in particular suffer because of the standard blurry screens. Not to mention scope sway from trying to hold your arms up. The engine sometimes struggles to track rotation points on break down weapons such as double barrels and over and unders, or guns may just piss off entirely. This aside, it hasnt affected my enjoyment in the slightest. 

The dev is brilliant and is without a doubt interested in producing a good product and not chasing a paycheck. His dev logs on youtube and the product itself are a testimate to this.

36119870.review: Hot Dogs, Horsehoes and Hand Grenades is possibly my favorite VR game ever created. Heck, it's probably up there with some of my favorite games ever made, period. With so much content and such open development, the game's value has only increased since I bought it a year ago. The detail in the simulation of each individual gun and their mechanics is incredible; I've learned more about how guns work from this game than any other I've ever played, or any instructional video I've ever watched, for that matter. For me, this is a must-own VR game if you're buying an HMD of any kind.

35869297.review:
[h1] After having a full day of play time for Hotdogs, Horseshoes, and Hand grenades (H3VR), I feel as if I have enough to make a proper review for anyone that wants to have some more information. As of this review, the game is in Beta but don't let that deter you. [/h1]

	If you’re a gun person, stop reading here and just go ahead and buy the game. You will like it.[i] I guarantee it. [/i]

	If you’re not a gun person and you hate guns, hotdogs, or good old fashion America, go ahead and move to England. I hear they don’t like guns or hotdogs there.

	If you fall in-between those two categories or you’re on the fence on buying the game, lend me your ears for a few minutes.

	H3VR is a realistic gun range simulator in the sense that all the firearms that have been provided function exactly as their real life counterparts do. The AK series of rifles have wonky magazine ejection systems, the pistols are fun and easy to shoot, and the M79 Grenade Launcher will shut if you slap it against something. 

	There are many different environments for you to fuck around in. Outdoor, indoor, Halloween themed, Christmas themed, sniper ranges, etc. If you like ‘spooky horror piss your pants when a hotdog with spikes tries to kill you’ scenarios, then boy oh boy do I have good news for you! There’s scene for that.

	If you’re a person that doesn’t like the teleporting mode for movement in VR, there’s about eight different options for movement. There’s the standard teleportation, a sliding mode, arm swinger mode, and more. The sliding movement mode is exactly that. You point where you want to go and you slide there as if you were walking. The arm swinger mode is a bit more realistic compared to the others. You hold down the touch pad down, and swing your arms. That’s it. It replicates the movement you would make if you were walking. It’s kinda weird at first, but it’s my favorite movement mode. Especially when fighting Wurstbots.

	The dev for the game, Anton, uploads development logs for the game every week [url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCAh_PNH5RK1VF-vXrANLElQ] Youtube [/url]. These weekly videos show what’s to come in the next update, improvements made, or sometimes shows how the game is made. If you don’t like youtube because of [INSERT REASON HERE], you could try Reddit [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/H3VR/] /r/H3VR [/url]. If you don’t like Youtube or Reddit…..iguessyouhavetowaitforupdatesonsteam…


	That’s a quick and dirty review. If you have any questions, leave a comment below and I'll try to privide an answer for you.

35727257.review:
The game is quite realistic on several aspects, the weapons look real, ammo and items too, aiming is better than in other VR games.
There are still things that really need to be improved like magazines reloads, they are a lot harder to switch than in real life because you can't feel them. It's a pain to aim the mag inside the weapon and if you want to do it fast you really have to be careful not damaging your controllers. In a real situation you don't have to look at the mag and the bottom of your weapon you just grab one and switch, there should be some better automation to get this result.

The recoil feeling and depth of sound would benefit a little more work too.
Also sometimes the pistol grip of the weapon doesn't match the controller hand position, making it odd to try aiming.

However I'm confident the dev will fix all this real fast because this is going to be the reference weapon handling and shooting for VR. This could lead to a new standard for all FPS games as funny as it is now just to play with VR guns and grenades this game is the coolest anti-stress break !

35093545.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
[list]
[*] I paid full price for item
[*] I love H3VR and its cheery developer
[*] I use H3VR as a tool more than a game
[*] I use an Oculus CV1 with Touch
[/list]

[h1] Who This is For[/h1]
I'd start off by saying that if you don't mind the cost at all, this is a great casual sim with loads of potential.  If you are money conscious like me, I'd tell you that this is not for a hardcore gamer as much as it is for someone who wants an outlet for casual (but realistic) gun mechanics and ranges.  

[h1]Development[/h1]
H3VR is stable and updates and new content are regular.  The developer is experienced and passionate about his work, and I'm very happy to see he smartly weighs development priorities.  The one real caveat—but well within his right—is that he is protective of how H3VR is used.  In recent times, he's been vocal on his limits for H3VR being used as a vehicle for objectionable content in the public space (or used to promote a product without permission).  From my analysis, his interpretation of "objectionable" is already in Twitch/Youtube TOS, so it's not anything outside the norm.

I'd tell you to sign on to the beta branch because that seems to be the route to go for the "bleeding edge" in terms of content.  Don't get too flustered if your favorite gun isn't already in there.  From my observation, the limit is available VR-ready models.  I also think he's got his priorities right making the overall improvements to modes and bugfixes.  As a modeler of 11 years, I can tell you modeling is a time-intensive operation, and that time is better served making the platform for your favorite gun as great as it can possibly be.  I personally have two guns I want in the game, but I'm probably going to end up modeling them myself because there's just so many others that could possibly be added (and PDWs is getting kinda dense).

Anton also seems to optimize well because even my R9 390 can handle the top settings and not chug under a metric ton of spawned guns and mags.  Only in the beta branch have I gotten some stutters in one area, but that's why its called the "beta branch".

[h1]Virtual Experience[/h1]
Within the scope of the game (not VR in general), I'd tell you that it's almost fully convincing.  I like how well thought out the use of the controllers are in terms of replicating the feel of manipulating an actual firearm.  It's clearly optimized for the Vive because some of the actions using the thumbsticks take a little practice.  You really want to consider a third of fourth camera.  That's smart in general, but also because the best locomotion is "Arm swinging mode", and in that mode, you can move (but not turn) by swinging your arms around.

I can sit down and just putz around in H3VR for 4-5hr intervals.  It's not lacking in engagement into the environment.

[h1]How I use It[/h1]
Personally, I use it like I would use a range in real life.  I've kinda given it more purpose than a casual sim.  Where I would normally spend $20-50+ on a range trip to get some serious practice in (I'm licensed to carry and keep my skills sharp), I can just fire up H3VR and do the same and more (hurray full auto, suppressors, and metal targets).  I by no means attempt to be some Gun-fu master or whatever, but I do want to make sure I have the muscle memory to react in seconds like I would in a real incident.  H3VR saves me money, and it may even save someone's life one day if I (god forbid) have to defend my/others/bystanders/etc lives.

Also, Anton's weekly devblogs brighten my week, so there's that too...

34944692.review:
As an Australian, it can be difficult to do anything with guns. Shooting ranges need licenses and permits let alone that they are hard to come by. Not only that but using anything above a bolt action rifle is highly illegal unless you pay a god awful amount at some indoor bunker government range to fire 8 bullets from a glock then go home with the target...

...This soothes my gun fantasies.

If you like guns and have VR get this game. thats pretty much it.

But note the word "game". Its pretty subjective considering the whole game is a glorified demo and mini game collection. this isnt a a statement against H3VR rahter just pointing it out what it is. The minigames are reasonably varied and the range choices are plenty but aside from the amount of guns to choose from, gameplay is pretty basic with target shooting and relatively dumb AI hotdog roll targets. However, the physics on the weapons, damage system of material based objects and detail of everything overall is quite a spectacle including real weapon mechanics employed. It is also early access, meaning more is to come.

If youre expecting a tactical combat shooter with weapon customization you are in the wrong place. If you are expecting simulated ranges, with targets of plenty and weapon customization and excellent physics then look no further.

34877244.review:
Hot Dogs, Horseshoes And Hand Grenades is a VR gun simulation game.

The gameplay is simple but very fun. The gameplay consists of picking different guns, loading and firing them. You can select many different firing ranges to go to which all look good and are unique.

There are also a couple different game modes. The one I found the most entertaining is The Grinder. In The Grinder you need to go around a maze to find peices of meat and bring them back to the beginning. In the maze there is a variety of robots that will attempt to kill you and they can surprise you if they are around corners. There's also many other game modes.

The price is very good for what you get. Even if only half the game modes were included I think it would still be worth the price.

What makes this game better is that the developer updates it very frequently. Every update usually brings many changes, gameplay additions and some new guns.

I can definitely recommend this game. If you have a VR headset you have to get this game.

34179731.review:
Do you like guns? 
Do you like shooting guns? 
Do you want to get as close to realism as you possibly can?

if you said yes to the above, then this game is for you. 

I've never fired an actual gun before, but this game makes me feel like I have. Figuring out how to load the gun and getting it ready for fire brings me such joy. The bolt action rifles are one of my favorites to fire- it's so satisfying to pull the boat back and watch the shell eject and slam it back in for another shot. 

The game has a few modes availible- some are a work in progress , while others are finished. Traditional indoor ranges, Sniper ranges, a mini-game like range that tests your aim, reflexes, and speed. It's all in good fun- From my time of purchase until now- I believe there have been two or three updates and the developer doesn't seem to be stopping anytime soon which is always a plus. 

The biggest issue that I've run into and is not the games fault, but VR's...is that looking down the sights to distant targets can get blurry due to the resolution. Other than that- it's awesome sauce. 

Putting some music on in the background and getting some practice in doesn't get old.  

I highly reccomend it.

Worth every penny. Even though it only says HTC VIVE it is 100% compatable with the Rift and the head dev Anton has been amazing. He posts frequent and entertaining update videos to his YouTube channel so be sure to subscribe if you buy this. 

Now thats the fluff over with lets get down to business. This is a gun simulator. You use guns in this game same as  you would in real life. You pick up the gun, put the magazine in and pull the slide back, flick the safety off and fire...if this kind of autism pleases you as it did me then you will be right at home here. It simulates firearms in a either a totally serious realistic way should you choose through the options or a more playful and fun way for beginners in the same way.

33907088.review:
Honestly. Where to begin?

The game is brilliant. A VR experience you should have if you own a VR headset. This is hands down one of the best Early Access VR Games you could buy right now. So much tender love and care has been put into every little nook and cranny of the guns you can use that it brings a tear to my Patriotic striken eye. (And I'm not even American!) The developer - Anton - is so dedicated to this project and so happy to work on it with bi-weekly updates with new content, bug fixes and as so heavily active in the community that he should be a Role Model for how you develop and run an Early Acess title.

Enough sucking the developers dick. Lets get into the meat of it. (eheheh... meat... puns...)

Pros:
- Multiple scenes for you to explore, play in and test weapons in the game alongside a few very fun objective based maps with interactables. Such as AI spawning, target practice (With multiple settings and variations to play.)

- Over a hundred guns to play with. And as advertised, each is accurately modelled and functions like the real life counterpart. (Sparing for some VR limitations, you still require the touchpad for some interactions, most of it is using your own two hands!

- Constant and active developer updates and developer himself. You'll get any answer you need from the H3VR reddit, where updates are posted with changelogs. You won't miss a thing and keep up with the memes!
- Slow to fast paced gameplay. Fancy shooting up some bots and running about? Or you just wanna load up an AK-47 or two and see how many times you can hit the broad side of a barn? Hell yeah you can! Your imagination is the limit - scenes provide you with plenty of visual stimulus to keep you entertained. And just exploring how the guns work and looking at their models is a load of fun!

- Weapon wackiness. Wanna put 13 red dot sights on your Mk-18, 3 sniper scopes and 9 laser dots? You might crash your game. But you can do it!

- Meat.

- Just buy it already.

Cons:
- It's still a WIP.

- Wait, Mister! Thats a con? Yes! It is, the game is still being made. There are unfinished features of the game that are on the list to be developed on, so your favourite section might not be updated for a long time. 

- There will be no Kollibri.

- Antons couch.

- There aren't really many cons. Game is gud.

33391809.review:
This game is "wonderful"; I love everything about it. Prior to getting my vive around Christmas, I had been eyeing this game for several months. After my initial list of games I purchased this one a little after the MEATS update was released and have loved every minute of it since. It is nearly my most played VR game (audio shield slightly wins right. Ow because my wife and guests play that in addition to myself). 

I originally only wanted a VR shooting range, but this game does so much more (in addition to the VR shooting range). MeatGrinder is a huge thrill and a ton of fun. MEATS offers a huge variety of ways to shoot. The indoor range and friendly 45 are my favorite ranges (I love the "trap shooting" on friendly45 even though I can only hit the pots. The most recent WURSTWORLD update is just incredible and is the real reason I'm writing this review. 

I normally try and get 1hour/$ in my video game purchases, but WURSTWORLD itself feels like an entire game. With ~16 hours at the time of writing, I feel like I've totally gotten my money's worth and extra. Anton, the dev, clearly puts so much work, thought, and love into this game. The physics are amazing, the game looks great and ran perfectly on my 980 before I upgraded, and the variety of guns and ammo is just astounding. I'm not even entirely sure I've used every firearm yet because there are just so many and Anton is continuously adding more. 

If I had to say one bad thing about this game, it's that you really need to watch Anton's dev logs in order to figure a lot of things out as the current in-game directions are lacking. However, Anton has mentioned this is something he is working on. 

This is a sandbox game, so don't expect a story line (although WURSTWORLD has a better storyline than a lot of other games I've played), but this is the definitive firearm simulation game for VR. I'm super excited for future updates and can't praise this game enough.

33253243.review:
[h1][b]About The Game:[/b][/h1]
Hot Dogs, Horseshoes & Hand Grenades is a Virtual Reality experience for both the HTC Vive & the Oculus Rift. A Firearms simulator at heart but not what I would consider a game.... YET! Hot Dogs, Horseshoes & Hand Grenades has only just gotten an update that has just started turning it into an actual game.

If you go into Hot Dogs, Horseshoes & Hand Grenades expecting a full on VR game then you will be slightly disappointed, however if you go into it expecting a Simulator or an Experience then you will be a very happy chappy.

The game is developed by a very dedicated & loyal developer that always puts the content and the community above the income. He's never released an update that I've been disappointed with to date. 

[h1][b]The Review:[/b][/h1]
Hot Dogs, Horseshoes & Hand Grenades is a very fluent, realistic, very detailed, lovingly crafted simulator. The firearms are modelled to their real life counterparts, the sounds are authentic to the real life counter parts & most importantly the FPS is solid smooth all the time. (Something that you should always expect from a Virtual Reality product.)

The controls work great, the firearms are modelled exceptionally well & each moving part flows smoothly with the animations. There's a lot of different movement options, graphical settings for weaker computers & plenty of gameplay modifiers to change the experience from realistic to playful. (If you choose.)

There's a large number of game modes in the game currently from Sandbox target shooting maps to indoor & out door rifle ranges, night ranges, etc. There's also a small number of actual game modes with moving targets and tagets that shoot back.

Currently the closest thing to an actually game experience is Meat Grinder & WurstWurld with targets that actually fight back & other little mini games to play. There's just so much content on offer here & it is getting better, I've sunk (currently) 100 hours and still haven't had enough of this experience.

[h1][b]The Verdict:[/b][/h1]

[b]The Bad:[/b]
Hot Dogs, Horseshoes & Hand Grenades while a fantastic VR experience isn't without its problems. There's bugs here & there & there's sometimes some bad physics but overall the worst thing about the game is that it does lack some actual game modes, things with enemies that fight back. Currently WurstWurld is slowly making progress towards that but it's still a little lacking.
[list]
[*]Lacking actual game modes.
[*]Buggy physics (at times).
[*]Occasional game mechanic failures which prevent further play without a map reset.
[/list]

[b]The Good:[/b]
While Hot Dogs, Horseshoes & Hand Grenades has its problems it also does a lot of good, I mentioned a lot of them throughout my review but I'll also add them here for those who would like me to just get to the point.
[list]
[*]A fanatastic & realistic sandbox Firearm experience from the comfort of your home. (And for those of us who don't have the money to spend on ammo all the time).
[*]Realistic & beautifully crafted weapon models that really are something to oogle.
[*]Realistic bullet drop & physics.
[*]Exceptionally fluent & well animated models.
[*]A constant 60+ FPS Virtual Reality experience.
[*]Plenty of customizability from graphical settings to gameplay modifiers.
[*]Lots of different Firearms to play with from Semi-Automatics to Bolt Actions to Lever Actions & of course Full Auto's.
[*]Constant and consistant updates that add more content. (Even if only small).
[/list]

This VR experience in my honest opinion is that it's a [b]MUST BUY[/b] if you have an Oculus or a HTC Vive you [b]SHOULD[/b] have this game.

[h1][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h1]
My final verdict from Hot Dogs, Horseshoes & Hand Grenades is a solid 8/10.

It just needs a lot more actual game modes to make this a 10.

32888360.review:
The Baron Reviews: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0vL7q4LHwCw

On paper, this game sounds pretty dull; shoot a variety of guns at targets. In reality it is one of the best VR experiences out there, and I think that can largely be attributed to the quality control and attention to detail put into the game by its dev. I don't particularly love guns in real life and I find the idea of owning/shooting gun kind of intimidating, but this has really been enlightening for me as an educational tool. The level of realism for each gun is so high, that after 20ish years of gaming where the majority of games involve guns and shooting of some kind, I was shocked to find that with an M-16 in my hands I had no clue how to actually fire it. All the small things; loading the right clip, flicking the safety, racking the slide, fiddling with the sights and attachments... I absolutely loved it as a learning experience. Plus, the little things, like I didn't know that after loading and racking a pistol, removing the clip still leaves one bullet in the chamber that can be fired. It was therefore surprising to me when I accidentally shot my virtual foot off, thinking the gun was safely unloaded. To me, this is one of those things where even if you are the most liberal, anti-gun person in real life, it's a damn good thing to at least understand how they work from a safety/preparedness point of view!

But it's not all educational and serious; In fact, for a game about realistic, lethal weapons, H3VR does an incredible job at not taking itself too seriously! There's tons of fun to be had with all sorts of varying game modes, from straight up target shooting at a range, to swinging out of the ceiling whilst shooting in a jungle gym type arena, to the terrifyingly intense meat grinder mode. As well as being able to spawn items to mess around with without limitation, there is also the ability to reset the environment back to its clean, original state. The variety of guns is large and fantastic, with a huge amount of quality and care in each one. With one exception, they are all true to their real life counterparts, but that one exception is a fictitious gun, the Cleric's pistol from the film Equilibrium (which was a total dream to get to shoot!). There are also some melee weapons to mess around with, as well as throwables and then some straight up silly items.

Graphically, the game is so well done. The guns and textures look amazing and some of the best I've seen in VR. The audio too is absolutely top marks, with fantastic attention to detail being placed on little things from the crack of the different calibers to the plink of the bullet casings hitting the floor. Gunfire also takes into consideration environmental reverb, so a rifle shot doesn't sound the same in the gunrange as it does outside. All these small things do such a good job at making the experience feel realistic.

The physics are excellent, with the ability to change how physics work from realistic to semi-realistic, or to not at all. I love realistic because I love the "feel" of the guns when you toss them on a table, though tossing grenades with realistic physics is a little tricky! I also absolutely love that the option is given to have no bullet casing cleanup, so you can see all the casings pile up on the floor. Other than that, interacting with guns can at times be a little niggly, especially with the Touch controllers, but I mostly chalk that other up to just the nature of doing anything with the motion controllers, plus a recent update helped tremendously with Touch calibration. 

Because of the mostly standing nature of the game, VR sickness was non-existent for me. You can move around the areas with a teleport, which works perfectly fine. I have no complaints about this game at all, but I do have two disappointments, of which sadly the debates on each have been soundly put to rest! I would have liked to (or the option to) been able to see my hands in game for immersion. However, due to the understandable technical difficulties in this task and potential bugginess it could cause, it isn't going to happen. But even more than that I wish so much that H3VR had a Workshop on Steam where modders could create fictitious guns from sci-fi or movies (like the RoboCop gun, Blade Runner, etc, or maybe even crazy things like a Proton Pack!). However, due to the complexity of adding guns and their physics, the game wouldn't be able to support the architecture for modders, so it is a sound no on that. The absence of these two thing are disappointing in the truest sense of the word, but in no way make the game any less incredible.

Even though its Early Access, the current game is polished like a full release. Updates have been consistent and substantial in content, with the dev being active on the forums and engaging with the community. If you love guns, this is a must play game. If you don't love guns, this is a must play game.

32687185.review:
8 out of 10

This is an adult playground for gun fanatics. It's less a game and more a sandbox of real weapons beautifully modelled in VR for you pick and choose and enjoy entire process of realistically loading and shooting. There's no quick reloads, you perform the actions authentically even down to inserting individual rounds into chambers of a revolver (or just use a speedloader).

The game is packed with a incredible amount of guns it's just enjoyable to spend half an hour spawning different weapons and slinging some rounds down range. To play with your guns you have a number of sections like ranges, competive test ranges, wave shooter, and even a survival horror game. Mind you I wouId say some of the sections are less interesting than the actual guns, but I commend the variety of activities squeezed in.

Hot Dogs, Horseshoes & Hand Grenades is unique, there's no other VR titles like it, but it won't be for everyone, the guns are amazing but the play areas all feel like work in progress. If you go in with the right mindset you'll have a lot of fun larking around with the authenic guns.

32159436.review:
As of today, (3rd of june 2017), I have played a full day of this game, so I wanted to write a review.

Before the actual review, a quick little FYI: I actually bought Vive for this game, especially THIS game.

So, pros...:

+ Great graphics
+ Nice maps
+ The attention to detail is amazing
+ Lots and lots of weapons to play with (and more are being added with each update!)
+ No need for a calibration, nor any struggles with changing to left handed 
  (I am left handed, so this is more of a personal +)
+ The developer has a nice devblog, communicates with the community and is a nice guy in general
+ All the content is a part of the core game, so no 100s of DLCs (looking at you Payday)
+ Great community
+ A comfortable handling of all the weapons

...and cons:

- Yes, the weapons are VERY detailed, but certain "kewl" things (such as the M4's forward assist) instead of being pulled, are just set to a button (again, kind of a personal one)
- For newbies, knowing what button does what can be difficult, but this is just a minor one, as it should stop being difficult during the first 1-3 hours
- On the map "friendly 45 range" sometimes occur small FPS drops (especially when scoping) , at least for me, (so again, a bit of a personal one), but this is a very minor one, as it dissapears after a while

But all things aside, this game is a masterpiece for the VR, and even though it has a lot of things, it is very well optimized (I have a 970 and it runs like a dream, but that is with most of VR titles, at least the popular ones,) very well made and the dev is just amazing.

I give it a solid 9.9/10 - if you have a 970 or better, a semi-good CPU (lower gen i7 should be alright), like guns in general, and have the money to buy a vive, then don't hesitate and just buy this game.

モデルガン・実銃・サバゲーなどが好きな人におすすめ！
ゲームとしては屋内/屋外など様々な場面のシューティングレンジが基本で、何かと戦う要素は今のところ少ないです。
ただし、シーン（≒ゲームモード）が10個以上あり、ものによっては簡単な戦闘やアトラクションなども出てきます
とても自由度が高いとはいえ銃の操作がかなり複雑なため、細かい操作を楽しいと感じる人に特におすすめです。

※たとえばリロード１つにしても様々な手順を踏むことができます。
１．フル装填マガジンを取り放題にして、デタッチ＆アタッチ（一般ゲーム風）
２．弾薬から空マガジンへ１発(複数個持つことも可)ずつ装填してからリロード（サバゲ風）
３．薬室を開けて弾薬１発だけ直接入れる（ロマン）

またピストルの２丁持ちが好きな人も、慣れると両手リロードができたりします！
１．マガジン排出
２．両方の銃をサイドポケットにしまって固定する
３．新しいマガジンを両手でそれぞれ持ち、銃にセット
４．撃ち尽くしていた場合はデコッキングレバーを使ってコッキング（手が塞がっているのでスライドは手動で引けない）

アップデートによってシーンや銃／部品／弾薬などがちょこちょこ増えているため、今後も楽しみ(´▽｀)

30248154.review:
I absolutely love this game, and the constant development and support make me love it even more.  Hot Dogs, Horseshoes and Hand Grenades (or H3) is an incredibly in depth gun simulator and allows you to load and shoot dozens of different real-life firearms, each with different reloading mechanics that require precice and fun use of your virtual reality motion controllers. Load shotguns by plugging each shell into the barrel, or load a .45 magnum bullet by bullet, this is as close to a shooting gallery in VR as you will find. Realistic scopes and a ton of different shooting ranges to choose from (as well as some mini games and obstacle courses) this game is absolutely worth the price of admission.

Here's a more in-depth video review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4bwBwIY1DtE

30109937.review:
This is a fun game full of potential that suffers from aggressively bad controls. 

The Good:  You get to shoot things and blow things up.  The graphics and design are quirky and fun, and there is a large array of weapons to choose from.  Did I mention you get to blow things up?  My favorite so far is the hand grenade skee ball.  There's also an obstacle course, firing ranges, and a host of fun things to do.  I could see spending hours in this.

The Bad:  The controls.  In their desire to make the use of the weapons as realistic as possible, the devs seemed to have forgotten (I'm sure they didn't forget...I'm sure the controls were the result of a lot of trades offs and I don't want to seem like I'm knocking them because it's clear a lot of effort went into this game) that the touchpad controllers lack fine motor control.  Picking up a cartridge to insert into a gun involves  a lot of helpless fumbling to get it to align properly.  There's also cocking the trigger and pulling back the barrel and attaching the scopes etc.  The point being, the game seems to require fine motor skills from a controller that lacks them, and it makes for frustration.

Additionally, when you're using the scope on a rifle, you have to shut one eye to see through it.  Can you guess why that's a problem?  And, again, because you're squinting at something, trying to sight something far away, small, incremental movements are required from a controller that doesn't really do small and incremental.  

There's also a weird bug that kept me from being able to pick most things up off the ground.  Not really a huge deal (and I did recalibrate my floor multiple times), but drop some bullets or a scope or a magazine? Just consider them gone and spawn new ones.  

Overall, I like the game.  But the more I played, the more my frustration grew.  I'm not entirely sure it's the fault of the devs.  I just wish there was a balance between the realism they're trying to achieve and reality of the controllers we have to use.

30073156.review: If you love guns, truely enjoy the mechanics of how a firearm works, and want to have the closest thing you can have to a gun range in your house, definitely buy this. If youre only interest with weapons is how many things you can kill, and all of your firearm knowledge comes from Call of Duty, get the hell out of here. I'm amazed that there are any negative reviews for this simulator at all. I know there are some teething issues still with the controls and the program itself, but it is being updated on a consistent basis that you rarely see anywhere else. If there is a problem, let the developer know. I guarantee you that it will be resolved in the next update or two, this guy rocks! If you are having problems learning the controls, take some time to play around with it and learn. Yes, a tutorial would be nice to have, but you're not going to jump right in and learn everything in 15 minutes or less. Lastly, if you're mad because you just wanted to pick up a gun and shoot stuff like every other game, it doesn't work like that in real life either. Having problems firing the M4? Go online and watch a video on how to properly load and fire an M4, you'll be fine after that. It drives me nuts, like the people that pickup Need for Speed, think they're amazing at racing games, then get super pissed at IRacing because the they keep spinning out. Some games are easy to pickup arcade games, others take some time and nuance to learn. Sorry this went from a review to a rant, H3VR is amazing!!! Some people just suck sometimes.

29685909.review:
본 게임은 어마어마 하게 재미가 있는 게임 같은거라기 보다는 VR을 사용하여 사격장을 제공 해주는 게임이다.
클레이사격, 큐브 부수기 미니게임, 그 외 기타 자잘한 게임들이 있는것 같지만, 그 부분은 깊게 하지 않았으므로 노코멘트 한다.
한국은 관광지의 권총사격장 정도를 빼면 사격장이 잘 없으니, 비록 반동이나 이런맛은 실제보다는 덜해도 충분히 대리만족정도는 되는것 같다. 

총기류의 작동은 상당히 잘 구현되어있는것 같다. 
총기마다 미묘하게 조작이 다르기도 하고, 리볼버 같은경우는 약실을 막 휘리릭 돌려서 척!하고 장전하는 제법 멋진 모습도 가능하다.
M16A1의 경우 사격장 절차대로 조정간 안전, 노리쇠 후퇴고정, 탄알집 결합, 노리쇠 전진, 조정간 단발, 준비된 사수 사격개시, 조정간 안전,  노리쇠 2,3 회 후퇴전진, 격발테스트까지 해볼수 있고, 방이 넓고 센서시야를 가리지않는다면 엎드려쏴 자세까지 가능하다.
심지어 발사 직후 튀어나온 탄피도 주울 수 있는 것 같지만 굳이 여기서 까지 탄피 회수하는 변태는 없겠지.

등장 총기류 중에 실제로 만져본 총이 예비군가서 쓴 M16A1이랑 군에서 닦는거 밖에 안해본 M1911 뿐이라 전부는 모르겟지만, 그 둘을 놓고 봤을때 다른 총 들도 실제 사용방식과 유사하게 잘 되어있는 것으로 보인다.
예비군/입대예정자의 사격장 수칙/절차 및 사격연습으로는 나쁘지 않을것 같다. 
당신도 이게임을 구매하여 특등사수와 예비군 사격 만점 조기퇴소를 노려라!


단점은 Vive 해상도 문제인지, 아니면 초점이 가늠자로 자꾸 잡혀서인지 제법 먼 거리를 조준할때는 가늠쇠가 흐리게 보여서 조준이 좀 힘들다.

추가로, 눈앞에 권총 총구를 대고 쏴보면 권총 자살 할 때의 기분을 약간 맛 볼 수 있는것 같다.

Note that you should turn down the volume before playing, lest you get hearing damage. It has realistic gun sounds, meaning big booms on shots. You can also use silencers to help negate sound.

29221863.review:
My favourite Vive experience. Really well put together, takes a bit of learning if you're not a gun owner/expert but there's plenty out there to cover you thanks to the very good dev logs. (I'm not, but I still love it!)

It's a sandbox experience with a stockpile of weapons for you to play around with - it's a lot of fun just tinkering with different guns and using them on a range, but there's also a 'breaching' mode, a short single player horror mode, an arena where you fight robots (which has a very well produced melee system), and a Climbey-with-guns style assault course.

The devs are extremely on top of things considering this is an early access title - a huge amount was added over December and there's plenty more to come, with updates every week. 

Really strongly recommend it!

29123988.review:
This has to be the stupidest title that hides a true gem. Had it not been for the most emphatic recommendation of a person I trust, I wouldn't even have looked at it. The goofy XMas-themed video that ran in the steam store also did its best to scare me off. 

So I bit the bullet (ooh, pun!) and purchased this title. 

Now, this game goes against *everything* I stand for and yet I still love it. Since I left the military 30 years ago, I haven't touched a real firearm, and I advocate strict gun control. This game is fun with guns and everything that goes bang. I should hate it, but I don't. It allows me to play with guns yet without experiencing any guilt - and it is brillianty implemented. Now, aiming sidearms one-handed feels very different (and is strangely difficult) from what I was used to, but maybe that's because it was so long ago. This is sheer fun, and the implementation of a sandbox firing range is pure genius (I just spend two hours straight at the 'friendly range'). Plus, this is one of the few room-scale only titles that really makes sense.

Oh, and heed the developer's advice to check your staps when using grenades...

After I'd successfully lived out a few John Wick moments with them, I'd noticed the arena mode. Simple me thought "Oh that should be kind of interesting, but it might get boring after a minute or two." I load up with a few guns, and set about looking for my simple-minded robot targets. I go up a few sets of ramps, and hear bullets flying toward me. Simple me was now as low to the floor as possible, trying hard as hell to load a mag into a rifle while being shot at by a menacing A.I beast. Never doubt the power of V.R, it may have looked dumb as hell to see a grown man curled up in a ball on the floor with two controllers in his hands, but my god is it amazing in the headset. 10/10 would desperately rush robots with a tactical knife with an American flag on it again.

28957527.review:
This was my first truly mind blowing experience in VR. 

In game, I picked up a rifle that I was familiar with in real life (Actual Reality?) and knew exactly what to do: how the magazine loaded, where the charging handle was, safety, etc. I was shooting targets right away. Then, I picked another rifle that I had no real-life experience with and I couldn’t operate it. Just like would happen if I were trying it in the real world without instruction. My mind was blown. This wasn’t 1st person shooter arcade style mechanics. To operate the gun, you had to know how it worked in real life.  This moment was a prime example of how a well-designed simulation in VR will change learning in the future.  

In short, the devs are putting a lot of attention to detail in this game. Is it Game? Partly. It is a blast to shoot targets and climb around monkey style in the “Gunnasium”. Also, throwing horseshoes and hand grenades at pumpkins isn’t a totally serious endeavor. That said, I think it’s just as accurate to say this is a small arms simulator.

TLDR;
Well executed simulation of going to the gun range with every small arm imaginable. A must have.

28922593.review:
This is definitely one of the more enjoyable Vive experiences so far, if you're looking to dick around with virtual firearms. The controls can take some getting used to, but there is a tutorial video on the store page and the game does let you fool around quite a bit. Want to play with grenade launchers, machine guns, SMGs, pistols and even grenades and a minigun? This is for you. Definitely worth the money. The graphics are a little mixed in quality and detail, with the guns being fairly well detailed but the environments themselves toned down in complexity, but the combination works. The interface is a little finicky at times, and the use of actual in-game items to control things like weapon spawns and area setup is a little wonky but it does work. The text might be a little on the small side for things like the ammunition respawn panel, however. 

You will definitely want to try and have a fairly decent roomscale play area available, This game spreads its setup areas out pretty well, but you should be able to manage in a pinch like I do.

Pros: Loads of guns, loads of ammo, loads of environments
Cons: Text can be a little tricky to read, UI takes practice to acclimate to

28879362.review:
Absolutely my favorite VR game currently.

I have so many games that I want to check out, but I keep coming back to this. As a new Vive owner, I'll break down the reasons why I love this game.

[list]
[*] I put drum magazines on two assault rifles, held one in each hand and shot up clay pots.
[*] I lit a stick of dynamite with a fireworks sparkler I lit from a box of matches and thew it, causing an explosion that blew a wooden chair across a night time Arizona field.
[*] I opened a Christmas "display" box with a lever which caused trap-style Christmas music to begin playing while cofetti fell - which revealed a sub machine gun with Reindeer antlers and red nose attachments for it's rails.
[*] I put 12 gauge dragonfire rounds into a tactical shotgun and shot them at a mountain at night to watch the awesome effects.
[*] I then put 12 gauge flare rounds and 12 gauge confetti rounds into the same shotgun.
[*] I emptied a revolver of it's ammo like a Western action film star, flipped in through my "finger" and pretended to holster it.
[*] Did I mention I loaded a 12 gauge tactical shotgun with explosive rounds and blew up watermelons?
[*] Last but not least, I loaded a gatling gun with a crate of ammo and shot down fences, bottles, watermelons, metal targets and more.
[/list]

Also, this all took place in only 2 out of over 15 different levels/scenarios included in this game. There are practice ranges with TONS of options, mini-games, and more.

If you like gun, like shooting things, or just like having fun - this should be the first Vive game you purchase.

28813285.review:
I wouldn't usually review a game that's early access, but this one was too awesome to pass up.

[b]Easy on Hardware[/b] - Usually a game of this scale and detail would absolutely annihilate my computer. The minimum specifications state that I should have a GTX 970 (currently running a 770, with every other minimum system requirement matching or barely exceeding). I can safely assume that the difference is minor, and has very little impact on the games performance. This is not to say that a 760 would perform just as well, but I figured that my system could set the system requirement at a lower bar. I played again today for the first time in 2 weeks to stress test the rig, and I found it to have a very smooth framerate. When I initially purchased the game a few months ago, the game was very jumpy on some modules. However, as of today I can easily tell that the developers have been working extremely hard to optimize the game even further.

[b]Realism[/b] - This is important for me. The very first thing I did after I installed the game was to pick up an M4 and go through the paces of loading it up, charging it, and eventually firing it. However, I was not expecting to actually have to use a safety switch in a VR game. That's when I knew that attention to detail was the games primary focus. Granted I DID buy H3 blind, so I wasn't really sure what to expect. I set the gun down and picked up a grenade. Like the biased approach that I had, I just threw the damn thing. Nothing. Turned out the pin actually had to be pulled. Well I'm an idiot. To me it was like opening a 10K piece set of legos, and being told "Go forth and prosper."

[b]Replayability[/b] - H3 is a sandbox game mixed in with various levels of weaponry and processed meat. Sure you can use all the weapons, and throw all the explosives currently available, but then your creative juices will start flowing and trickshots and speed runs will eventually ensue. After spending 20+ hours in the game between multiple accounts, I always seem to find something new to do and test out.

[b]Dev Updates[/b] - The amount of updates that get pumped into H3 are astronomical. Yes I am writing this review when it's still early access, and I know it could potentially slow down as the months progress. It's not necessarily the amount of updates that makes this an important category for the review. It's the developers focus on what should be updated for the game. For example, I've seen many cases where other game developers will push multiple updates through the week that have new additions for the game, but completely neglect the known bugs or other playability issues. This is not the case for H3. It's a nice steady mix of additions and fixes that allow the players to continually explore new things, while re-playing existing content with fresh fixes. Not only does the developer update the game, he (Anton) also loves to push video updates on youtube to show the H3 community what's new, what's been updated, and what's on his mind for the future of the game.

[b]Player Support[/b] - What I've found out recently is the amount of support that the team gives towards the games community. I've seen and experienced a lot of interaction between the dev team and the community. Which is absolutely fantastic. After chatting with a member of the team regarding a suggestion, I was informed that the team highly encourages community feedback. That's what early access is all about. Becoming involved with the game, and providing feedback to the team to make the game as successful as possible. 
(Thanks Luke for your time!)

[b]Difficulty[/b] - One thing that threw me off was how diverse the weapons are. I love to shoot, and have shot A LOT of weapons over the past few years, but I found quite a few weapons in game that took me a bit of time to learn how to operate. For players or future players that haven't fired a weapon before, don't fret. The game isn't a "stump the dummy" kind of game. It's more of a learning opportunity than anything else. In a many cases, once you learn a type of weapon, you've actually learned the mechanics of a few others.

[b](TL;DR) Final verdict[/b] - Overall, purchasing Hot Dogs, Horseshoes & Hand Grenades was well worth it. I couldn't really think of a con or complaint for the review. Sure others will have differing opinions with the game, but the overall attention to detail stood out for me, and really highlighted the potential for a successful future full release.

28757324.review:
Wow, update 45.  Just a mere thirteen updates ago I considered the game to be lacking in content and a glorified mobile firearm simulator.  While I stand by my point then, the game at this point deserves to be recognized for what it is, and hopefully where it will go.  I have to judge a game based on what's available, and over the past two months the developer has worked extremely hard on providing two very, very robust modes as well as updating some of the older prototypes.  There is a survival horror mode, a wild west world to explore, and two smaller modes that are good for just some free form target shooting.  Want something more mellow?  There's a shooting gallery.  Even more mellow?  There are several shooting scenes.

No matter how you want to experience the most lovingly crafted firearms I've ever seen in a game, you'll have something to do.  While it's still very much an experimental product in a lot of ways, it's perhaps one of the richest VR firearm experiences you'll find with an emphasis on physicality and deserves a strong recommendation.

28503097.review:
In terms of simulation, this is the best Vive "game" around. It simulates all aspects of weapon handling/shooting that I can think of with some VR toppings like challenges and "robits" (robot drones) to spice things up. While I put "game" in quotation marks (H3VR is more of a sandbox than a game), it does contain several minigames which are all very enjoyable on their own. 

Mastering each of the weapons is fun and I make a point of firing up the game every time a bunch of weapons are added just so I can try them out. Anton, the developer, updates the game several times a week which means there's always a lot of new features and weapons to try out even if you play the game semi-frequently. 

[b]Performance[/b]:

I've never had noticeable frame drops in this title even when playing with an entry level VR system. 

[b]Comfort[/b]:

The game covers a variety of locomotion options from teleport to Touchpad sliding. It goes above and beyond and offers plenty of customization options for both locomotion and other game mechanics as well.  

[b]In summation[/b]: 

If you're a gun nut and enjoy range shooting, this has to be a staple in your library. It's really that simple. 

If you're like me and not a gun nut but would enjoy going to the range nonetheless, I also recommend this game as it's a lot of fun to play with realistic and fully functional weapons in such a detailed, intuitive, feature rich, and polished sandbox. 

I would go even further and say it's a must have for Vive users.
